intro: Tetraplasandra pupukeensis var. decipiens, commonly known as the False Pohutukawa, is a rare and endemic plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Araliaceae and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and distinctive, showy flowers. The plant typically grows in coastal and lowland forest environments, preferring well-drained soils. Its leaves are opposite and ovate, with a glossy surface, while its flowers are small and clustered in umbels. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
